output.conclusion: This course provides an expert-level understanding of fluid mechanics, equipping you with the knowledge and skills to tackle complex engineering challenges involving fluid behavior.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Fluid Mechanics! This course delves into the complexities of fluid behavior, building upon foundational concepts to explore advanced topics relevant to expert-level engineers and researchers. We will cover topics from advanced tensor analysis to multiphase flows.

chapters.description: Review of tensor algebra and calculus. Introduction to curvilinear coordinate systems. Application of tensors to represent stress, strain, and rate of deformation in fluids.
Classification of non-Newtonian fluids. Discussion of various constitutive models (e.g., power-law, Bingham plastic, viscoelastic). Application of these models to solve flow problems.
Discussion of temperature and pressure dependent viscosity models. Introduction to thixotropic and rheopectic fluids. Modeling of complex fluid behaviors.
Derivation of the Navier-Stokes equations in curvilinear coordinate systems. Application to complex geometries. Numerical methods for solving the equations.
Introduction to hydrodynamic stability theory. Linear stability analysis using normal mode decomposition. Application to classic problems like Poiseuille and Couette flow.
Mechanisms of transition from laminar to turbulent flow. Discussion of bypass transition and other non-classical transition scenarios.
Derivation of the RANS equations. Discussion of the closure problem and various turbulence models (e.g., k-epsilon, k-omega SST).
Introduction to LES and its underlying principles. Subgrid-scale modeling. Application of LES to complex turbulent flows.
Overview of DNS and its computational requirements. Application of DNS to fundamental turbulence research.
Derivation of the governing equations for compressible flow. Introduction to the equation of state for ideal and real gases.
Analysis of normal and oblique shock waves. Rankine-Hugoniot relations. Applications to supersonic and hypersonic flows.
Introduction to expansion waves and their properties. Application to supersonic nozzle design and aerodynamic problems.

chapters.chapterTitle: Boundary Layer Equations for Compressible Flows
chapters.description: Derivation of the boundary layer equations for compressible flows. Effects of heat transfer and pressure gradients.
Analysis of thermal boundary layers. Solutions for different boundary conditions (e.g., constant wall temperature, constant heat flux).
Development and application of heat transfer correlations for various flow configurations.
Classification of different multiphase flow regimes (e.g., bubbly flow, slug flow, annular flow). Flow regime maps.
Introduction to two-fluid models for multiphase flow. Interfacial transfer terms and closure relations.
Description of Eulerian-Lagrangian methods for simulating dispersed multiphase flows. Particle tracking and interaction models.
